# wildcard fallacy

Only five consonants in hard / weak form:

## one sign generating all words 'PTRM=VCLN'

ğ’Œ“ Values:	aâ‚â‚‚, ahâ‚ƒ, alâ‚…, amna, araâ‚‡, ayaâ‚“, babâ‚‚, babar, babbar, barâ‚†, baraâ‚“, berâ‚‚, beÅ¡â‚â‚‚, birâ‚‚, daâ‚‡, dadagâ‚“, dagâ‚‚, damâ‚‚, eâ‚ˆ, galâ‚ˆ, haâ‚…, hadâ‚‚, hadaâ‚‚, haÅ¡â‚ƒ, heÅ¡, his, hiÅ¡, hudâ‚‚, kumâ‚„, laâ‚‡, lah, lih, luhâ‚“, par, para, per, peÅ¡â‚â‚‚, pir, pirigâ‚‚, piriÅ‹â‚‚, raâ‚ƒ, saâ‚â‚†, salah, sikiâ‚‚, Å¡amaÅ¡, Å¡araâ‚‰, Å¡arag, taâ‚…, tam, tama, tuâ‚‚, á¹­amâ‚‚, uâ‚„, ud, ugâ‚„, ulâ‚†, umâ‚‚, unâ‚…, ut, uta, utu, uá¹­, waá¹£itâ‚“, zalaâ‚“, zalag, zalaga, zalah, zalaqaâ‚“


TODO: rewrite  

There are universal sound changes and seemingly odd changes specific to languages.  

It is often reasonable to assume a very blurred out distribution for a particular Reading:  

Look at the cluster Pod-Pfote-bein-boot-foot-ferse ... covering everything from p to f  

after 3000 years in the Egyptian language we can suspect many such broad traces *combined* :  

Unfortunately [sound-change](sound-change.html) and even [alphabetic-change](alphabetic-change.html) are very real, we just need to be very careful.  
Linguists today are very careful, which is good. Unfortunately this carefulness might go too far and result in [Bad-Linguistics](Bad-Linguistics.html) of the second kind: Highly plausible connections get rejected due to some dubious sound change law, as if language strictly abides to laws at all times.  

D-DT-T  
T-TH-S-C  
D-DS-S (demi - semi)  
C-CH-CK-K  
D-DZ-DJ-DCH-CH  

combining two of these can lead to a Spektrum leading from K to D, which is not a usual sound change.  

asides from the ordinary sound changes and R-L in Egypt we find an affinity of  
NV  
NM  
MB  
MW  mit/with mo/wood  


Traces between (semi)vowels don't help  
W-U-OO-O-OA-A-AR W-R etc  

quickly all letters of the alphabet can be reached with just three or four consonants: M T P R  

Thus giving a sign the infamous sequence ÂµPTR can lead to almost all words in the dictionary if we allowed substrings. ÂµPTR=map.tr ÂµPTRâ‹pthrâ‹prthâ‹price â€¦  pick any word.  

Thus one needs to be very careful avoiding this sequence or extending known words with 'just an extra m or r'.  

That's a dilemma because some words actually might have had such a sequence / cluster  
P-T-R father ...  
ğ“†‘ PTHN? probably PTH â‡” 'PSI' though  
CEPHAL (head) â‡” KOPPER â‡” CAPUT.ma  

For [ğ“†‘](ğ“†‘) at least the pain can be alleviated:  
Axiom 8: Most letters had a full (original) reading and an alphabetic one.  

ğ“¶ MAS/PRO/CEN  

fortunately these appear in quite **specific** sequences & contexts.  

In those cases one must be careful abusing the blurriness for words which probably have such sequence.

# atomization
Usually splitting words into components is the epitome of the wildcard-fallacy, yielding almost any desired reading.  
Thus whole word comparison must be preffered under all circumstances even if compartmentization seems very plausible as in the case of [chariot](chariot.html) [ğ“Œ](ğ“Œ.html).  

One must not overemphasize or misinterpret the direct translations either.  
Even thouth ğ“Œ ğğ—ğ‹ğğš mrkbt /markabtu/ is a perfect match, it could still be a loan with secondary connections.  
ğ’ buÊ³ bear in ğ’•ğ’ da-buÊ³ the [Bear](Bear.html) ×“×‘× debÄ å¤§ !  

In some cases a split reading is strongly supported by [Coptic](Coptic.html), but even this might be some kind of [PSM](PSM.html) :  
ğ“‚‹ ğ“ˆ– ğ“Šª ğ“†¶ ğ“†° renew   â²“â²£â²“ â²›â²ƒâ²‰â²£â²“
